description:
Patagioenas fasciata, commonly known as the band-tailed pigeon, is a species of pigeon native to western North America. It belongs to the genus Patagioenas, which includes several species of pigeons and doves.

The band-tailed pigeon is a medium-sized bird, typically measuring between 32-39 cm in length and weighing around 300-500 grams. It has a distinctive pattern of gray and white on its wings and body, with a dark band near the tip of its tail. The species is known for its ability to fly long distances and its tendency to form large flocks, particularly during the breeding season.

Patagioenas fasciata is an important game bird and a significant part of the diet of several predators, including raptors and mammalian carnivores. The species is known to play a crucial role in the ecosystem as a seed disperser, contributing to the regeneration of various plant species.

The band-tailed pigeon inhabits a range of habitats, including coniferous and mixed forests, oak woodlands, and urban areas. Its distribution extends from British Columbia in Canada to central Mexico, with populations found in various regions of the western United States.

Overall, the band-tailed pigeon is a well-studied and ecologically significant species that has adapted to a diverse range of environments in western North America.
